data_findings.finding: This is a 2D bin packing optimization problem: pack Christmas tree shapes (15-vertex polygons) into smallest square bounding box for n=1 to 200 trees. Score = sum(side^2/n). Lower is better.
Tree geometry: 15-vertex polygon with trunk (0.15w x 0.2h), base tier (0.7w), middle tier (0.4w), top tier (0.25w), tip at y=0.8. Reference point is center of trunk top.
Key technique: bbox3 C++ optimizer using simulated annealing with complex number vector coordination, fluid dynamics, hinge pivot, density gradient flow, and global boundary tension.

Key technique: fix_direction rotation optimization - uses scipy.optimize.minimize_scalar to find optimal rotation angle (0-90 degrees) that minimizes bounding box side length using convex hull of all tree points.
Overlap detection uses Shapely STRtree for efficient spatial queries, checking polygon.intersects() but not polygon.touches() to allow touching but not overlapping.
Multi-phase optimization strategy: Phase A (short 2min runs), Phase B (medium 10min runs on top candidates), Phase C (long 20min runs on best few). Uses bbox3 with different n and r parameters.

Backward Propagation technique: Start from n=200 and work backwards, removing trees that touch the bounding box boundary to potentially improve smaller configurations. This exploits the fact that good n-tree solutions can be derived from good (n+1)-tree solutions.
Use long double precision in C++ for better numerical accuracy. Tree coordinates and angles benefit from higher precision calculations.

Rotating Calipers algorithm: For finding minimum-area bounding rectangle, at least one side must be collinear with a convex hull edge. This allows O(n) search after computing convex hull. Used in fix_direction optimization.

web_research.query: What are the best algorithms for 2D irregular polygon packing optimization problems?
web_research.finding:
Two‑dimensional irregular polygon packing – where pieces may have arbitrary shapes and can be rotated – is a classic combinatorial optimisation problem that appears in sheet‑metal cutting, textile layout, furniture design and many other manufacturing settings.  Because the search space grows exponentially with the number of pieces, exact methods are only feasible for very small instances; most state‑of‑the‑art solvers rely on sophisticated heuristics and approximation schemes that balance solution quality with computational speed ([frontiersin.org](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fmech.2022.966691/full)).

The most effective approaches reported in recent literature fall into three families:

web_research.query: What are the best techniques for minimizing bounding box area when packing non-convex polygons?
web_research.finding:
Minimizing the area of a bounding box for a non‑convex polygon is usually tackled by first reducing the shape to its convex hull, because the smallest‑area enclosing rectangle must also enclose the hull – the optimal rectangle will have at least one side collinear with an edge of the hull ([wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minimum_bounding_box_algorithms)). Once the convex hull is obtained (in \(O(n\log n)\) time for a general polygon), the **rotating‑calipers** method can be applied to examine all candidate orientations in linear time, yielding the exact oriented minimum‑area bounding rectangle ([grokipedia](https://grokipedia.com/page/Minimum_bounding_box_algorithms); [blog](https://geidav.wordpress.com/2014/01/23/computing-oriented-minimum-bounding-boxes-in-2d)). This two‑step pipeline (convex‑hull → rotating calipers) is the most reliable exact technique and is widely used in computational geometry and graphics.
